BE11:19am

Otherwise, here's Credit Suisse talk copper supply

BE11:20am

As we recently wrote in our supply tracker (Mine Supply Tracker: Q416 and 2017 outlook: iron ore supply im proving, copper turning negative) we expected global supply to turn negative in 2017. Based on the mid-point of company guidance across the 15 companies that we track would point to 2017 YoY supply growth of just under 2%, but, based on a typical level of disruptions (of around 5%), mine supply is likely to be down 2-3% YoY (CS forecast -2-3% mine supply growth). WBMS data however last week reported global copper m ine production was up ~8% YoY in January; in our view this was predominantly a result of Jan/Feb being the weakest months in 2016 with several projects (e.g. Las Bambas and Cerro Verde in Peru) making a material contribution from March onwards. The YoY comps should therefore get progressively harder through 2017 especially given the strike/disruption impact from Escondida and Grasberg through February and March. At the end of last week, workers at Escondida (~5% of global supply) reportedly ended the strike that had lasted for ~6 weeks. However, newswires have reported that the workers invoked a legal provision to extend their old contract and therefore negotiations will need to resume within the next 18 months (rather than the typical three year labour settlement).

BE11:20am

None of which is why they're down. They're just down.

The Ignite strategy is beginning to bear fruit and underpins double digit EPS growth over the next four years. Growth is moving from new vehicle sales to aftersales, self-help and M&A; broadening the global presence and quality of the business. With consensus forecasts behind the agenda and valuation failing to capture the emerging business, we return to Outperform.

Bounce Bounce Bounce

PM11:23am

BE11:23am

The investment case has undergone a sharp U-turn over the past 6 months. The macro backdrop has improved and there would now look to be upside risk to the demand environment. Currency has turned from a headwind to tailwind. Management have iterated a credible self-help programme to support earnings progression. M&A has moved from optionality to reality.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

UK isn't that much of the group any more, and all the other markets work on their own slightly opaque trends.

BE11:25am

New disclosure gives visibility on the earnings support despite slowing new car demand. The aftersales tailwind underpins organic profit progression in FY17 and beyond, which alongside leverage, cost savings and an ongoing buyback underpins c.10% EPS CAGR across FY16-20. M&A adds 10-15% optionality
M&A is back on the agenda. The recent South American acquisition was a text book example of Inchcape’s renewed focus allowing them to leveraging their positioning to find value accretive M&A. Many more opportunities exist, and we estimate utilising existing balance sheet power and near-term cash generation could add 10-15% to Inchcape equity value.

BE11:25am

Upgrade to Outperform (from Neutral). TP £10.50 (from £7.35), 30% upside (Blue Sky c50%)
The relevance of the macro and structurally challenged UK retail sector to Inchcape is diminishing. We move to a SOTP valuation. Valuing the retail assets on 8x and the Distribution assets (adjusted for over-earning Singapore) on 11x underpins our £10.50 target price. The blended c.10x implied Mar-19e EBIT multiple and c.7% FCF yield doesn’t look challenging given the growth agenda.

PM11:01am

Welcome to Markets Live

PM11:27am

Falcon Acquisitions

11:27 am
PM11:28am

Falcon, the international media group focused on the over-the-top ('OTT') video streaming market, is pleased to announce its shares have commenced trading on the London Stock Exchange's ('LSE') Main Market under the ticker FAL. In conjunction with commencement of trading, the Company has raised £4 million, before expenses, through a Placing of new Ordinary Shares at 25p each. The funds will be used to transform Falcon into a leading OTT broadcast media company based around Q-Flow, the Company's revolutionary software, which is proven to prevent the frequent loss of signal or 'buffering' that currently affects the OTT video streaming market. Shard Capital Partners LLP acted as Joint Broker on the Placing together with Nuovo Capital LLP, which is also the Company's Financial Adviser.

BT Group (BT.A:LSE): Last: 321.80, down 3.85 (-1.18%), High: 322.70, Low: 318.70, Volume: 8.00m
BE11:40am

As I say, it's not really significant to current numbers ....

11:40 am
BE11:40am

... that's to come later. Here's Cazenove to talk us through "later".

BE11:41am

Regulation is, unfortunately, an everyday part of life for BT Group. With the Openreach settlement behind us, attention now turns to the Wholesale Local Access (WLA) review that Ofcom is due to launch before the end of March. Its significance for BT and the wider industry shouldn’t b underestimated. This is the key regulatory mechanism that Ofcom can use to shape and incentivise investment in the UK’s “full” fibre future. We expect it to solidify market expectations around a mid-term uptick in capex for BT (£100-200m pa from FY19). We expect some near-term drag on Openreach revenues and profits from changes to regulated prices. But we don’t expect this drag to be materially different to what is already baked into guidance (approx. £150m pa).

BE11:41am

Four issues in one consultation. The WLA will set out Ofcom’s proposals in four key areas: 1) charge controls for (S)MPF (aka local loop unbundling for standard broadband); 2) charge controls for GEA (fibre-to-the cabinet broadband); 3) the new framework for PIA (access to BT's ducts and poles); and 4) forward looking minimum service levels (MSL) required of Openreach for installations and fault repairs.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

A framework to stimulate more investment in “full fibre”. Ofcom wants to stimulate more investment in “full” fibre networks. To do this, the regulator needs to carefully balance the input costs for today’s copper-based broadband products with the input costs and effective availability of tomorrow’s “full” fibre broadband products (via access to BT’s ducts and poles). This likely means little change to current MPF charge controls but with the potential for more significant increases over the mid-to-long term to encourage investment in a third infrastructure.

BE11:41am

Estimate revisions. We are making some small changes to our estimates for BT, primarily increasing capex by c£100m pa from FY19 to reflect an anticipated step up in investments in “full” fibre and improvements to rural broadband. Consensus bakes in this increase from FY18 which we feel is too early. We also lower EBITDA in FY19 to capture the step up in content costs following the recent UEFA rights renewal.

PM11:43am

State of the art trains: We will introduce 750 new, spacious train carriages for the Windsor, Reading and London Suburban routes by December 2020, as well as 18 additional, fully refurbished trains (90 carriages) on the London-Portsmouth route from December 2018. We shall deliver 52,000 more peak seats per day at London Waterloo compared to today’s services by December 2020. The rest of our mainland fleet will be refreshed and will have free, more reliable Wi-Fi, at-seat charging points and free infotainment as well as real time travel and connection information screens.

PM11:43am

(My parents still live in Portsmouth, so relevant for me..)

PM11:44am

Station improvement: £90m will be invested in our stations, including a major refurbishment at Southampton Central station.

11:44 am
PM11:44am

Dunno why they's waste money on that tho

PM11:45am

Here's a bit of Shore

PM11:45am

FirstGroup has this morning announced that along with its JV partner MTR, it has been awarded the South Western rail franchise. FirstGroup has a 70% stake in the JV.

The new franchise will start on 20 August 2017 and run for a core period of seven years, with a potential eleven month extension at the DfT's discretion. For those on the line they can look forward to 750 new carriages by December 2020, 90 brand new trains, a halving of the average fleet age, c30-45% more capacity at peak times, reduced mainline journey times, improved Sunday services, mobile ticketing and charging points as well as £90m of station investment.

11:45 am
PM11:45am

There is a conference call at 8.30am this morning where we expect more details on FirstGroup's financial targets for the franchise. Our early estimate is that based on 6% per annum turnover growth (capacity is going to increase remember) and a margin of 4% over the life of the franchise, this franchise award could be worth c£170m to FirstGroup shareholders.

Even without this award, we believe FirstGroup stands on the cusp of the long waited inflection point in its earnings and cashflow, before today's announcement we forecast a net FCF yield to March 2018 of 11.5% and an imminent return to the dividend paying list.

BE11:45am

.................................... hm.

BE11:46am

I don't know how investors are meant to value this stuff.

11:46 am
BE11:46am

Just cutting to UBS

BE11:46am

The company has disclosed that the premium payments to the Department for Transport amount to a NPV of £2.6bn (using a real discount rate of 3.5%) which should yield about £3bn over 7 years in absolute terms, although the company was not willing to give any detail regarding the initial payment and growth profile thereafter in its conference call. The winning bid also sees FGP commit to a loan of £30m, £88m in contingent loan facilities (of which £88m is bonded), a performance bond of £15m and a season ticket bond of £80m.

BE11:47am

I can sort of understand why management wouldn't want to give their growth curve ... but not disclosing the initial payment looks a bit odd.

11:47 am
BE11:48am

I mean, rail franchises have a nasty habit of not delivering anywhere close to what's expected.

BE11:48am

Not getting to know what they take upfront seems unnecessarily secretive.

BE11:48am

Here's Canaccord.

11:49 am
BE11:49am

Average revenue growth over the life of the new South Western rail franchise is expected to be in the same range as the historical average of 6.9% (2009-2016). Whist underlying revenue growth has decelerated in the last year or two, 750 new carriages should deliver significant capacity and revenue growth from December 2020 onwards. Margins are expected to be comparable with the recent overall industry average of around 3%. Premium payments to the government over the life of the franchise are expected to total £2.6bn in real terms. There is an element of revenue protection through GDP and central London employment (CLE) mechanisms, with revenue support/sharing to the extent that GDP and CLE deviate (beyond a ‘nil band’) from expected baselines throughout the franchise. There is also a profit sharing mechanism.
In terms of financial commitments, loan facilities are provided by the shareholders of the winning JV to support working capital and capital investment. This includes a shareholder loan of up to £30m and a £88m subordinated contingent loan facility (50% bonded). In addition, there will be a £15m performance bond and a season ticket bond of up to £80m.

BE11:49am

Our new earnings forecasts reflect today’s franchise win. Adjusted EPS forecasts have risen by c.5% for 2018E and nearly 8% for 2019E to 12.9p and 14.9p respectively. We have rolled forward our valuation year to 2018E, which has lifted our target price from 110p to 125p. This target price is based on a prospective earnings multiple of 9.7x, broadly in line with its 5 year average.

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

Since listing declines in oil and gas activities have dragged on earnings and valuations across the sector. We remain positive on Exova with its leverage to product quality and regulation in growth industries and potential for rebound upon any pickup in resources. We remain a BUY awaiting news of firm offers and price reaction this morning.

BE12:01pm

And Barclays ............

BE12:01pm

If Exova were to be valued at 12.2x FY17e EBITDA (£66.8m), this would imply a share price of c255p vs. Friday’s close price of 219p. We note that profitability in Exova’s Oil & Gas division is currently depressed however and there may be significant cost synergy opportunities available; for example Exova’s own corporate costs (plc, LTIP) are forecast to be c£3.5m in FY17e.

Exova trades on FY17e 10.6x EV/EBITDA falling to 9.5x in FY18e; 17.1x FY17e PE falling to 15.9x in FY18e.

In comparison Intertek trades on c13x FY17e EV/EBITDA falling to 12x in FY18e and c21x FY17e PE falling to c20x in FY18e.

12:01 pm

should be viewed as supportive for the broader TIC space. We see increased confidence in
oil and gas reaching a trough with more general industrial markets also improving.
